topic: “He couldn’t stand up so I hit him over the head with my bass. He fell to the floor. I ran away… I didn’t know if he was still alive”: The bassist who survived Fairport Convention, Jethro Tull and believing he’d murdered his bandmate on stage

ideas.title: The Espy Gig From Hell
ideas.premise: A cartoon panel depicting the bassist running from The Espy, bass in hand, chased by a swarm of irate musos and bouncers all yelling 'Ya mongrel!'
ideas.why_funny: Classic Aussie understatement meets rock excess, with local pub culture thrown in.

ideas.title: Fairport's Convention (of Band Meetings)
ideas.premise: The Fairport Convention band holds a meeting, everyone is wearing a helmet and padding, nervously eyeing the bassist.
ideas.why_funny: Plays on the absurdity of the situation and the band's cautious approach now.

ideas.title: The Moomba Bass-ker
ideas.premise: The bassist, dressed as a Moomba clown, is attempting to busk with his bass, but instead accidentally knocks people over.
ideas.why_funny: Moomba is a very Melbourne thing, mixing slapstick with local cultural reference.

ideas.title: Tull Tales: Flute's Revenge
ideas.premise: Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull, wielding his flute like a weapon, chases the bassist through Hosier Lane's graffiti art.
ideas.why_funny: Reimagines Anderson's flute as a weapon of vengeance within Melbourne's iconic laneways.

ideas.title: Cricket Bat Vs Bass Guitar
ideas.premise: A split panel showing the India/Australia T20 cricket match on one side and the bassist accidentally knocking out his bandmate with his bass on the other, both accompanied by excited commentators.
ideas.why_funny: Juxtaposes the (accidental) violence with the excitement of the cricket, a popular national sport.
